summary: Email correspondence between prosecutors and law enforcement regarding the tracking of FBI 302 reports and interview notes in the Epstein case. The emails discuss missing documents, clarify which interviews have notes versus formal reports, and mention over 120 interviews conducted.

events.title: FBI interview with IN
events.description: FBI agents met with an individual referred to as IN and have both a 302 report and notes from this meeting.

events.title: Prior FBI interview with IN
events.description: FBI conducted an interview with IN, but the 302 report from this time does not include information found in a later report dated 12/04/18.

events.title: Prior FBI interview with IN
events.description: Another FBI interview with IN was conducted, with similar documentation issues as the 2006 interview.

events.title: Report date reference
events.description: A report has a generated date of 12/04/18, but it is unclear if an interview actually occurred on this date; it may be a system-generated date.

events.title: Interview notes inquiry
events.description: Prosecutors inquire about missing handwritten notes from an interview on this date, noting the 302 report is very short.

keyFacts: The document reveals that there have been more than 120 interviews conducted in the Epstein case, indicating a large-scale investigation.
Prosecutors are actively tracking and cross-referencing FBI 302 reports and underlying interview notes, highlighting meticulous document management.
Confusion exists regarding the date of a report (12/04/18) and whether an interview with IN actually occurred then, suggesting potential documentation inconsistencies.
The correspondence shows collaboration between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and FBI agents to ensure all interview records are accounted for.
